data.content:
The components are divided into two modules: Definition and Function
For convenience it is recommended to divide the two modules into two separate files.

Each component can be associated with an interface to specify the types related to method states and refs.All the functions available in the component will be correctly configured without any further intervention.
getRef and getRefs will return e.g. HTMLElement or HTMLElement[] automatically.
The state type parameter ( dynamic type check ) will not be validated by typescript.
Specific types available, useful if you want to split the component into specific functions.
createComponent is the function that will take care of define and register our component.

A component to be used must be specified as a web-component. Once rendered the DOM generated by the component will take its place. Tag name must start with a lowercase letter, contain a hyphen, and satisfy certain other rules listed in the web component specification's.
The component function launched when the component is created.
An array with the definitions of the components used within it. It is necessary to load dependencies before initializing the application.
An array of states visible from the outside, e.g. from the parent component.
The states of the component. the state of the component is based on the store defined in mobCore and inherits all its functionality
bindStore allows you to couple the component state to another store ( mobStore ) taking advantage of its reactivity.
If the component function returns as first node the tag specified in the definition it will be possible to use the component as a web component and manage its lifecycle.

By default, onMount functions are launched at the end of the rendering of the current block of html, normally a page or the updates of invalidate and repeat, using scoped = true the onMount function will be launched just after the rendering of the single component and before the rendering of the next one.

Once the function has been executed and the HTML block has been rendered, it is no longer under the control of the library. Using the parameters invalidate, repeat, bindEffect, etc.. you can modify the DOM based on the state change. The function utils are in fact the only elements that will remain 'alive'.
The component function can be asynchronous. It is therefore possible to perform fetches and similar operations before rendering the DOM
Reactive management of classes, styles, text, and DOM refs
Event handling for components and shared DOM nodes
Managing a component instance and its methods
Managing DOM node updates, reactive collections, and on-the-fly component generation
Specialized components, slot patterns, and web component support
Managing classes directly on component instances ( non reactive )
